title: Opening Ceremony

author: Daniel Shapiro, Institute for the Study of Learning and Expertise

segmentation: So I'm going to talk to you just a little bit that introduced the innovative applications of AI conference for this year.
It's the 23rd conference I'm the chair, Markus Fromherz, who wasn't able to be here this morning, is the Co chair.
And the mission of iwi is different than the mission of AAA.
I we are focused on successful applications of AI technology, so this extends to issues and methods and lessons learned when developing applications and also when deploying applications.
The second main focus is to promote the interchange of ideas between basic and applied AI, and as a result we divide the conference up into 2 tracks.
One track focuses on deployed applications and these are AI based systems that are being employed by their final end users for some period of time it ranges from.

From a relatively short period of time on up to multiple years and what we're interested in are the experiences in both developing and deploying, and the lessons learned that come from the feedback in the actual application, and then the second track is on emerging applications which are about ongoing efforts that are very clearly motivated by applications.
So there is an application in hand.
I'll tell you a little bit more about how those tracks are distinguished.
The conference has five deployed applications.
There are 14 emerging applications.
It's a single track conference and it will be going on in parallel.
Feel free to come and go as you choose.
In looking at the iwi talks, I'd like you to evaluate them with a slightly different spirit in mind.

Then, when you evaluate a talk at triple AI, you should look at it and say you know what applications are feasable Now, what applications are almost feasible, and try and take away that inside of where your work is relative to that application chain.
And it is worthwhile looking for surprising applications because I have seen over the years these these endeavors move into the most wonderful and strange places.
My favorite paper from years back was on the classification of mackerel from from non mackerel, on and on a fish boat that was automatically processing these fish.
It will be an amazing places.

The requirements for the papers then segment into the emerging tracks and the diploid track for all papers were interested in task description, the application description and the uses of AI technology and for the diploid papers in particular.
The reviews.
Also ask questions about the application payoff.
Is it actually providing benefit to users to end users to businesses?
The profit motive is perfectly reasonable too.
Put in a paper of this kind.
Is the in the application development in a deployment?
Discuss that process?

What were in fact the difficulties and then even the maintenance of such systems viewed as a software product that has a lifecycle and issues and we'd love to see the benefit added and the issues that have arised in terms of the maintenance.
We have three invited talks.
Wolfram is already mentioned David Ferrucci's talk we have also, I'll take these out of order.
A second invited talk on another challenge problem.

So David Gunning from Vulcan will be talking about Halo book and its progress towards digital Aristotle which is a challenge problem in deep semantic artificial intelligence and common Lopez de Montargis from the Artificial Intelligence Research Institute and the Spanish National Research Council.
Will be giving a talk on a range of.
A range of capability talking about playing with cases, rendering expressive music performance with case based reasoning.
The last thing I'll say is that we give an award for the diploid applications.
If representatives here I'll just ask them to stand up when I read the name of the paper, there are five.
The 1st paper is news Finder.
Automating an artificial intelligence, new service, and this is Lang Dong Reed Smith and Bruce Buchanan.
Then if you were here, congratulations.
The second is the news that matters to you.
Design and deployment of a personalized new service and this is Mark Stefik and Lance good.
And then we have learning by demonstration technology for military planning and decision-making deployment story.
This is my challenge now.
Karen Myers, Jake Kologist, Chick Kolonja legal Tim Cummings, Tom Garvey, Melinda Visio, will Haynes, Chris Jones, Janet night, tell David Morley and William Onward and Scott Parker.
Yeah not bad.
And then we have machine learning and sensor Fusion for estimating continuous energy expenditure.
And this is a nice obvious Jonathan Faringdon, David Andre and Ivo's Devarick.
So many of you here.
And Lastly, the glass infrastructure using common sense to create a dynamic place based social information system.
Catherine Havasi, Richard Bull.
Boy Boris said kill Steen Polychronis.

If for Multiplus John Ferguson, Henry Holtzman, Andrew Lipman, Dan Shields, Matthew Blackshaw, Greg Elliott, Anesha keying and one last thing about that that paper, we've moved it to 11 Thursday on Thursday from 9:30 in the morning on Thursday.
So please do not the time change in any case.
Thank you to all those authors.
And.
Please enjoy.
